title: U.S. Moves to Expel Cuban Diplomats From U.N. Posts
text:
President of the United Nations General Assembly Maria Fernanda Espinosa, left, and Cuban Minister of Foreign Affairs Bruno Rodriguez Parrilla met in Havana in April.

The Trump administration moved to expel a pair of Cuban diplomats from their posts at the country’s mission to the United Nations, alleging they attempted to conduct “influence operations” against the U.S. ahead of next week’s gathering of world leaders in New York.

The Cuban mission to the U.N. didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. The State Department didn’t elaborate on the alleged offenses or the timing of the diplomats’ departure.

State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus said Thursday the U.S. requires the immediate departure of the two diplomats, whom she accused of “abusing their privileges of residence.”

Ms. Ortagus said the U.S. would continue to investigate potential wrongdoing at the Cuban mission, and that its remaining diplomats would see their travel essentially restricted to the island of Manhattan, where the U.N. is based. A separate State Department spokesman said it wasn’t “permissible for individuals to use their diplomatic positions as cover for engaging in activities that ...are prejudicial to the national security of the United States.” The U.N. General Assembly session ramps up next week with addresses from President Trump and other leaders. The Trump administration has reversed the diplomatic opening to Cuba engineered by President Obama and imposed new sanctions. In recent months, the U.S. has banned cruise ship travel to Cuba and limited the amount of money that Cuban Americans can send to their relatives on the island. Mr. Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo have repeatedly accused Cuba of exacerbating the political and humanitarian crisis in Venezuela, where authoritarian leader Nicolás Maduro clings to power despite U.S. and international support for opposition leader Juan Guaidó. There is recent precedent for the U.S. removal of foreign diplomats. In March 2018, the Trump administration said it was expelling 60 Russian diplomats in response to the poisoning of a former Russian spy in London, which British and American officials said was carried out by Moscow’s agents. Among the 60 were 12 Russians serving at the U.N. in New York whom U.S. officials said were intelligence officers. —Warren P. Strobel contributed to this article. Write to Courtney McBride at courtney.mcbride@wsj.com

description: The Trump administration moved to expel a pair of Cuban diplomats from their posts at the country’s mission to the United Nations, alleging they attempted to conduct “influence operations” against the U.S.
